quiz.title: Exponential Decay Applications
quiz.subtitle: Unit 9 Quiz 5: Modeling Real-World Decay with Exponential Functions
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Applying Exponential Decay Models to Real-World Scenarios

questions.question: A car depreciates in value by 15% each year. If you buy a car for \$25,000, which equation models its value after t years?
questions.explanation: 15% depreciation means it retains 85% of its value each year, so decay factor = 0.85. Initial value = \$25,000. Exponential decay: $V(t) = 25000(0.85)^t$.

questions.question: A radioactive substance has a half-life of 5 years. If you start with 800 grams, how much will remain after 15 years?
questions.explanation: Half-life means half remains every 5 years. After 5 years: 400g. After 10 years: 200g. After 15 years: 100g. Formula: $800(1/2)^{15/5} = 800(1/2)^3 = 800(1/8) = 100$ grams.

questions.question: The population of a town is decreasing at a rate of 3% per year. If the current population is 12,000, what will it be in 10 years?
questions.explanation: 3% decrease means 97% remains each year: decay factor = 0.97. After 10 years: $12000(0.97)^{10} \approx 12000(0.737) \approx 8,840$.

questions.question: Medicine in the bloodstream decays exponentially with a half-life of 4 hours. If a patient takes a 300 mg dose, how much remains after 12 hours?
questions.explanation: 12 hours is 3 half-lives (12 ÷ 4 = 3). After 4 hours: 150mg. After 8 hours: 75mg. After 12 hours: 37.5mg. Formula: $300(1/2)^{12/4} = 300(1/2)^3 = 300(1/8) = 37.5$ mg.

questions.question: Which of the following functions represents exponential decay?
questions.explanation: Exponential decay occurs when the base (growth/decay factor) is between 0 and 1. 0.88 is between 0 and 1, so $y = 500(0.88)^x$ represents decay. All others have bases > 1 (growth) or are linear.

questions.question: A computer loses 20% of its value each year. If it was purchased for \$1,200, when will it be worth approximately \$500?
questions.explanation: 20% loss means 80% remains: decay factor = 0.8. Equation: $500 = 1200(0.8)^t$. Solve: $500/1200 = (0.8)^t → 0.4167 = (0.8)^t$. Testing: $(0.8)^4 = 0.4096$, close to 0.4167. So about 4 years.

questions.question: A lake's pollution level decreases by 12% each month after cleanup begins. If the initial pollution is 500 ppm, what is the decay factor?
questions.explanation: 12% decrease means 88% remains: 100% - 12% = 88% = 0.88. The decay factor is what remains after each time period, not the percentage decrease.

questions.question: The temperature of coffee cools from 180°F to 140°F in 10 minutes. If it cools exponentially, which equation could model its temperature after t minutes?
questions.explanation: Exponential decay: $T(t) = initial \times (decay\ factor)^t$. Test 0.97: After 10 min, $180(0.97)^{10} \approx 180(0.737) \approx 133°F$, close to 140°F. This models exponential cooling better than linear or growth models.

questions.question: A forest decreases in area by 5% each decade due to development. If it currently covers 800 km², what area will remain after 30 years?
questions.explanation: 5% decrease per decade means 95% remains: decay factor = 0.95. 30 years = 3 decades. Area after 3 decades: $800(0.95)^3 = 800(0.857) \approx 686$ km².

questions.question: Which situation would NOT be modeled well by exponential decay?
options: A bank account with compound interest
Cooling of a hot object in a room
questions.explanation: A bank account with compound interest typically shows exponential GROWTH, not decay. The other options are classic examples of exponential decay: radioactive materials decay, cars depreciate, and hot objects cool exponentially toward room temperature.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of exponential decay! You can identify decay situations, calculate decay factors, and apply decay models to various real-world scenarios.
scoreMessages.70: Strong decay modeling skills! Focus on: 1) Calculating decay factors correctly, 2) Distinguishing decay from growth, 3) Setting up proper decay equations from word problems.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress with decay concepts. Practice: 1) Decay factor = 1 - decay rate, 2) Exponential vs linear models, 3) Half-life calculations, 4) Testing models with sample values.
scoreMessages.0: Start by understanding: Exponential decay means decreasing by a consistent percentage over time. Decay factor = what remains (e.g., 15% decay means 85% remains = 0.85). Half-life means half remains each time period.
